bibl.title: Partial transcription by J.G. Woods of 1914 letter from Henry Cabot Lodge to Theodore Roosevelt, [February 16, 1935]

div1.p: Woods transcribes part of a 1914 letter from Henry Cabot Lodge to Theodore Roosevelt concerning the successful use of mosquito netting against yellow fever in 1850.

div1.head: Partial transcription by J.G. Woods of 1914 letter Henry Cabot Lodge to Theodore Roosevelt, [February 16, 1935]
div1.opener:
54 Eleanor Road
Springfield, Mass.
Letters of Theodore Roosevelt
and Henry Cabot Lodge, Vol. 2,
page 444. April 6, 1914.
H. C. L. to T. R.
div1.p:
I cannot resist telling you something that I
heard from Captain McCoy. He was called on a short
time ago to make a survey and report on the Darien Canal
route. In looking up the subject he came across an
account of an expedition we sent there some time in the
fifties. It is, as you know, a particularly unhealthy
region. This expedition of the fifties was divided into
three parties. Two of the parties were eaten up by fever,
many died and all were desperately ill. The third party,
to which was attached the surgeon who made the report,
went through the worst parts of the valley and had no
illness at all. The surgeon attributed it to the fact
that he made them all use mosquito nettings, but, instead
of making the deduction which would have rendered him
famous, his theory was that the mosquito nettings kept
out the miasma at night!

It seemed to me a very interesting incident
when you think how that surgeon, sixty years ago, was on
the brink of the great discovery, but made the wrong de-
duction.

I trust your mosquito nettings have had the same
effect and for the true reason. This was after Roosevelt's
return from the South American trip to the “River of Doubt.”
